clinical_study.brief_title: Longitudinal Study of Children With Concussions
clinical_study.official_title: Longitudinal Study of Children With Concussions: 3-year Follow-up of Cognitive and Emotional Function, Return to Sports, and Risk of Re-injury

lead_sponsor.agency: Ann & Robert H Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago

clinical_study.source: Ann & Robert H Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago

brief_summary.textblock:
For children and adolescents who have had a concussion resulting in prolonged symptoms (>3 months), the investigators will:
1. Measure post-concussion symptoms, cognitive and emotional function during the 3 years post-injury.
2. Determine length of recovery and frequency of return to prior level of sports participation.
3. Determine the incidence of and risk factors for subsequent concussion during the 3 years post-injury.

primary_outcome.description: All of the following measures will be aggregated using PROMIS - a computerized survey tool: what sports are played by the participant, whether or not the participant has quit a sport (due to concussion or not), development of anxiety or depression post-concussion, changes in peer relations post-concussion, change in cognitive function post-concussion, and if the participant has been subjected to a stigma after being diagnosed with a concussion.

study_pop.textblock: Children Ages 8-17 who present to one of the Lurie Sports Medicine clinics for care of a concussion.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Patients between the ages of 8-17 years old who present to one of the Lurie Sports Medicine clinics for care of a concussion.
2. English-speaking patients
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients outside of the 8-17 years old age range
2. Patients who show structural abnormalities on neuroimaging.
3. Non-English speaking patients
